bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Albert E. Truby, April 25, 1936

div1.p: Kean discusses the unjustified claims in the Gorgas biography by Burton Hendrick and Marie Gorgas, relates news of an old acquaintance and of his health, and expresses his sympathy for Cuban sensitivity about Finlay.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Albert E. Truby, April 25, 1936

opener.dateline:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON, D. C.
/36
April 25th

div1.p:
I dont believe I
have yet written to thank
you for the copy of Walter
Reeds letter to you of Dec.
10th 1900 and for your
good letter of April 3rd27/36?
It is a letter of great
value & interest- I wish
I had had a copy of
it to send to Burton
Hendrick
AC
T
2
where in 1924 he and Mrs
Gorgas published their life
of Gorgas and made the
astonishing statement that
Reed when he discovered
that mosquitos could carry
yellow fever didnt know
what to do about it or how
to attack them and that
Gorgas was the real dis-
coverer when he found out
by his mosquito work in
Havana in the spring &
summer of 1901 that the
mosquito prevention did
actually put an end to
its prevalence in Havana!
It still makes me angry
to think of Hendrick doing
this when I had called
his attention to Reed's letter
to Dr L. O. Howard and
other evidence including
Reeds conclusions in his
address to the Pan American
Med. Congress in Havana
Feb. 4th 1901- I sent him
all the evidence in the spring
of 1924 when he published a
preliminary chapter in the
magazine the outwork I think
months before the book appeared
But it would have spoiled his
AC
T
4
story & made a lot of work
so he thought he would risk
it- Then Ireland made me
write the review of the book
which was published in
the Mil. Surgeon March 1925-
This & the reprints had a
wide circulation & killed
the sale of the book. Hen-
drick soon sold his share
in it & it slid quickly into
the oblivion which it deserved
tho. it was well written &
interesting- The trouble with
Hendrick was that he was a
newspaper man who thought
the story was more important
5
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON, D. C.
than the truth- Mrs Gorgas's
conscience hurt her but she
was blinded by adulation
and the glare of publicity
well I have gone a long way
from where I started-

Ireland who never forgets
friends asked me to go with
him to call on poor old
Col. Coe, as he does about
once a month- The old old
fellow lives in the past
and is entirely forgotten by
most of his former friends and
lives on these visits of Irelands
AC
T
6
Ireland arranged that on
his 80th birthday Gen Reynolds
would call on him with us
and Gen R. sent him a
five official letter of con-
gratulations & wrote me for
the Chief of Staff to send-
It made a happy day
for the old man who now
can hardly read at all-
I can beat him at that
game for now I can read
good point (not newspapers)
with the help of a strong
hand glass- I have just fin-
ished reading The Seven Pit-
lor of wisdom by Lawrence
of Arabia in a beautiful
7
edition with fine large
print with which I got
along very well- I dont
think the obscuring band
across my pupil has been
absorbed to any extent
but I have learned a
good deal by practice
in holding the focus of
my strong lens so I
get on much better as
far as reading is con-
cerned-

To go back to Walter Reed
I have had several letters
from Moran in Havana
AC
T
8
inclosing articles from the
newspaper El Mundo
saying that the “Yanke's”
rob Finlay of the credit that
belongs to him by always
talking of Reed & Gorgas
and failing to mention
Finlay- There is a certain
amount of the truth in that
Finlay, and Guiteras pointed
out in his speech at the dinner
given to Finlay at which
Gen. Wood, Reed Gorgas & I
were present did the same
role for Y. F. as legands Reed that Manson
did apropros of Ronald Ross- We
all agreed to that- Love to
Mrs Truby-
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours KEAN If you do not remember my reviews of Gorgas's life I
think I can dig you
up a copy
